Dec 15, 2016

New York’s Defensive Shortcomings Prevent Them From Further Succeeding

After highlighting a positive offensive start of the season, the Knicks still need to shore up defensive wounds

Folks, your New York Knickerbockers are in sole possession of third place in the Eastern Conference, at 14–11, and yet, it feels as though it’s a bit of a fluke. Have they exceeded initial expectations? Absolutely, but why does it feel as though they aren’t a true contender despite their record and ranking in the Eastern Conference?

Well, there’s a few significant points we need to touch on. The first, and most obvious, is that the Knicks cannot, and will not, possibly continue to beat every bad team, while losing to every good team this season. The parity is staggering; this is a team that handles bad teams relatively well, but has been absolutely decimated by the likes of the Cleveland Cavaliers (twice) and the Boston Celtics, two teams slated to make up the top two or three teams in the East.

The second point, is the lack of balance the ‘Bockers have displayed relative to their offensive and defensive prowess. As of today, before tonight’s nightmare, er, I mean, SuperTeam matchup versus the Golden State Warriors, New York ranks 13th in ORtg at 104.6, but 26th in DRtg at 107.7. So, the offense is not the concern, with Kristaps taking a massive stride thus far this season and with Derrick Rose finding his groove. So what’s up with the defense?

Kyle O’Quinn Continues the Knicks’ Tradition of Showing HBCU Athletes Can Ball
New York’s big man is another man following the steps of some Knicks greatstheknickswall.com

I tried to start with the eye-test. What, or who, has been killing us on that end? The obvious answer is Joakim Noah, and the starting lineup with him has a DRtg 107.5, and the starting lineup with Kyle O’Quinn inserted at center for Noah has a DRtg of 121.9. Next, those same lineups with Justin Holiday inserted over Courtney Lee had DRtg’s of 104.6 with Noah, and 97.5 with O’Quinn (via NBA.com/Stats).

So how do we make sense of this?

To zero-in on specifically how O’Quinn and Noah, the two bigs playing the most significant minutes at the center position, are getting beat up on the defensive end, I took a dive into the different play types and situations that the Knicks have been exposed to relative to Noah and O’Quinn being the primary defenders.

Post-Up Situations

  • As a team, the Knicks are allowing .94 Points Per Possession (PPP), which is the 6th highest PPP for post-up situations.
  • They also allow the highest free-throw frequency in the league in these situations, at a clip of 24.1 percent, and they also allow the highest frequency of and-ones, at 4.9 percent.
  • Furthermore, the rank 24th in turnover frequency, forcing turnovers at a frequency of only 10.5 percent.

This, of course, matches the eye-test, and this is important. There is an overload of statistics in today’s NBA, and often times more casual fans don’t agree with the numbers because of what they perceive to be true while they are watching the game. Pertaining to Noah and O’Quinn, we knew they were getting killed on the defensive side of the ball, but it’s a bit more clear now as to how it’s actually happening.

I’ve noticed what exactly they’re doing wrong in this scenario and many times they aren’t doing their work early enough. All too often, Noah and especially O’Quinn allow opposing big men to establish their position on the block early in a possession. O’Quinn has a tendency to get sealed off fairly easily, along easy buckets down low. By sealed, I mean that whoever O’Quinn is defending establishes their position closer to the basket, where their body is facing the hoop. This shouldn’t happen, as it’s the defender’s responsibility on the block to angle his man away from the hoop.

Noah, on the other hand, tends to allow baskets more by being a step slow than poor position. O’Quinn likes to hang back more towards the basket on defense as well, where as Noah likes to play up more towards the free-throw line and scramble back at times, and he’s been too late, too often.

I will caveat some of the blame on Kyle O’Quinn’s considering that over the last two weeks he’s played much better basketball.

Pick-and-Roll/Handoff Situations

  • Pick-and-roll statistics are broken down into two categories; ball-handler, and roll man.
  • For the ball handler, the Knicks are allowing 0.82 PPP, good for 12th in the NBA.
  • For the roll man, 0.92 PPP, good for 5th in the NBA.
  • For hand-offs, typically coming immediately after a screen set by the initial ball-handler, the Knicks allow 0.90 PPP, 17th in the NBA.

This is a time when the numbers don’t exactly matchup with what we see during the games. For pick-and-roll situations, if you go strictly by the numbers, it would appear as though they are fairly stout, ranking 5th and 12th, respectively, in the league for PPP. However, what these statistics don’t account for is where the Knicks actually tend to get killed on the pick-and-roll.

What tends to happen is Derrick Rose hedges up high and hard towards the man setting the screen; this is a tactic used from when Rose was in Chicago. The hard hedge was useful when you can lead a defender right into a prime Joakim Noah; that’s no longer the case. What happens now is the ball handler blows by Rose, and Noah, O’Quinn, and yes, even Kristaps, are slow to rotate.

Kristaps Porzingis does an excellent job of using his length to protect the rim, but there are many instances when he’s simply too late on a rotation. After the ball-handler blows by Rose, and the bigs meet them late, the Knicks scramble, and are immediately susceptible to a kick-out for a wide-open three-pointer (see both games versus the Cavaliers this year). After a poor start, Rose has been playing better on the defensive end, still not good by any means, by it has improved, even if it’s slight.

Rotations

Simply put, nobody rotates or switches when they are supposed to. Guys are late, and often caught out of position. Kristaps is a prime culprit here. Now, Porzingis ranks at, or in the top three in rim protection, and allows a low percentage around the hoop as well, but the issue is how often he isn’t around the basket. Yes, he’s 21. Yes, he will be fine in the long-run. Right now, he is not the best at rotating. He’s slow to do it, and at times he overcommits on the perimeter (see any game versus Kevin Love). This puts him out of position and at times out of the play entirely.

Can the Knicks Be an Efficient Team?
New York is on the verge of being a truly solid team this season. How do they push forward? Efficiency.theknickswall.com

Carmelo Anthony is also notorious for this, and he tends to try and come in and swipe the ball in a block attempt to compensate for being out of position. ‘Melo is actually a capable defender when he’s matched up on the block with an opposing power forward, but when he’s dragged out on the perimeter it’s hard for him to get back in time.

If the Knicks truly want to contend this season, they’ll need to shore up their defensive deficiencies. Obviously, it’s important to note how exactly they’re underperforming, because against teams like the Cavaliers, with Kevin Love and Tristan Thompson, the Toronto Raptors with Jonas Valanciunas, and the Boston Celtics with Al Horford, it is imperative that the Knicks fix their frontcourt defensively.

New York has an offense working pretty well right now, but without a solid defensive presence, they will face only an uphill climb from now to the postseason.

— Kyle Maggio, senior writer
